# Measures of central tendency {.section-title background-color="#c5b4e3"}

## Overview of descriptive statistics / summary measures

::: {.fragment fragment-index=1}
* Purpose of descriptive statistics?
* Purpose of summary measures?
    * Summarize a characteristic of a [distribution]{.underline} using a single number/score
        * Contrast to frequency distributions and graphs showing whole distribution
    * Advantage: efficient
    * Potential disadvantage: could obscure important information about the distribution
:::

:::: {.columns}

::: {.column width="50%"}
::: {.fragment fragment-index=2}
::: r-fit-text
> [**Measure of central tendency**]{style="color:#e93cac"}<br>single numbers used to convey<br>what is typical, common, usual, or<br>average in a distribution of scores
:::
:::
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
::: {.fragment fragment-index=3}
::: r-fit-text
> [**Measure of variability**]{style="color:#e93cac"}<br>single numbers used to convey the<br>diversity or heterogeneity in a<br>distribution of scores
:::
:::
:::

## Measures of central tendency

<br>

::: {.fragment fragment-index=1}
#### Purpose

* *convey what is typical, common, usual, or average in a distribution of scores using a single number*
:::

<br>

::: {.fragment fragment-index=2}
#### Most common measures

* Mean
* Median
* Mode
:::

## Measure of central tendency: Mean

:::: {.columns}

::: {.column width="60%"}

<br>
<br>
<br>

::: {.fragment fragment-index=2 style="font-size: 3em"}

$$
\bar{X} = \frac{\Sigma  X_i}{N}
$$
:::
:::

::: {.column width="40%"}

<br>
<br>

::: {.fragment fragment-index=1}
::: r-fit-text
> [**Mean**]{style="color:#e93cac"}<br>The [arithmetic average]{.underline}<br>of the scores in a<br>distribution equal to<br>the sum of all scores<br>divided by the<br>number of scores<br>in the distribution
:::
:::
:::

::::

::: {.fragment fragment-index=3 data-id="box1" style="background: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0); border: 3px solid #e93cac; width: 90px; height: 85px; margin: 10px; position: absolute; top: 290px; left: 115px"}

:::

::: {.fragment fragment-index=3 data-id="box2" style="background: #e93cac; border: 4px solid #690c48; border-radius: 15px; width: 210px; height: 100px; padding: 0px 0px 20px 10px; position: absolute; top: 430px; left: -50px"}
[***X Bar***]{.underline} refers to the mean of a variable called ***X***
:::


::: {.fragment fragment-index=4 data-id="box1" style="background: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0); border: 3px solid #1b8883; width: 70px; height: 80px; margin: 10px; position: absolute; top: 240px; left: 277px"}

:::

::: {.fragment fragment-index=4 data-id="box2" style="background: #2ad2c9; border: 4px solid #1b8883; border-radius: 15px; width: 300px; height: 100px; padding: 0px 0px 20px 10px; position: absolute; top: 100px; left: 0px"}
[***Sigma***]{.underline}: summation sign meaning *add up everything that follows*
:::

::: {.fragment fragment-index=5 data-id="box1" style="background: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0); border: 3px solid #a68100; width: 72px; height: 80px; margin: 10px; position: absolute; top: 240px; left: 352px"}

:::

::: {.fragment fragment-index=5 data-id="box2" style="background: #ffc700; border: 4px solid #a68100; border-radius: 15px; width: 300px; height: 75px; padding: 0px 0px 20px 10px; position: absolute; top: 120px; left: 322px"}
[***$X_i$***]{.underline} refers to the individual values of the variable ***X***
:::

::: {.fragment fragment-index=6 data-id="box1" style="background: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0); border: 3px solid #6e8e13; width: 72px; height: 80px; margin: 10px; position: absolute; top: 350px; left: 320px"}

:::

::: {.fragment fragment-index=6 data-id="box2" style="background: #aadb1e; border: 4px solid #6e8e13; border-radius: 15px; width: 225px; height: 60px; padding: 0px 0px 20px 10px; position: absolute; bottom: 130px; left: 322px"}
[***$N$***]{.underline} = total number of cases
:::

## Example calculation

::: {.fragment fragment-index=1}
### Mean of age for a group of 10 individuals

Ages of sample members: 21, 34, 19, 20, 25, 41, 21, 23, 20, 18

:::

<br>

::: {.fragment fragment-index=2 style="font-size: 1.5em"}
#### [Calculating the mean]{.underline}

$$
\bar{X} = \frac{\Sigma X_i}{N} = \frac{X_1 + X_2 + X_3 + ... +X_n}{N}
$$

:::

::: {.fragment fragment-index=3 style="font-size: 1.5em"}

$$
       = \frac{(21 + 34 + 19 + 20 + 25 + 41 + 21 + 23 + 20 + 18)}{10}
$$


:::

::: {.fragment fragment-index=4 style="font-size: 1.5em"}

$$
       = \frac{242}{10} = 24.2years
$$

:::

## Important properties of the mean

1. Appropriate only for interval-ratio variables
    * must be able to assume consistent units/values for mathematical operations
2. Mathematical balancing point of the distribution
    * [magnitude of scores below the mean balance the magnitude of scores above the mean]{style="color:#e93cac"}
    * Example: Annual salary of a sample of teachers ($1000’s)

#### Mathematical implications of the balancing-point property  

[![](images/mean_deviations.png){fig-align="left" width="80%"}](https://www.onlinemathlearning.com/mean-balance-point.html#google_vignette)

::: {.fragment fragment-index=1 data-id="box5" style="background: #c5b4e3; border: 4px solid #754cbc; border-radius: 15px; width: 300px; height: 515px; padding: 0px 0px 20px 20px; position: absolute; top: 100px; right: -75px"}
[**Deviation**]{style="color:#e93cac; font-size:2em"}<br>[*(from the mean)* <br>The difference<br>between an<br>individual<br>score/value<br>in the<br>distribution<br>and the mean of<br>the distribution]{style="font-size:1.5em"}
:::

::: {.fragment fragment-index=1 data-id="box1" style="background: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0); border: 3px solid #e93cac; width: 290px; height: 25px; margin: 10px; position: absolute; top: 160px; left: 20px"}

:::

--- 

#### Mathematical implications of the balancing-point property 

::: {.fragment fragment-index=1}
* *The sum of the differences between the scores in a distribution and the mean of the distribution always equals zero.*

::: {style="font-size:1.9em"}
$$
\Sigma(X_i -\bar{X}) = 0
$$
:::
:::

::: {.fragment fragment-index=2}
* *The sum of the [squared differences]{.underline} between the scores and the mean is smaller than the squared difference between the scores and any other point / value in the distribution.*
    * [*scores in any distribution are more clustered around the mean than around any other point*]{.fragment fragment-index=3 style="color:#e93cac"}
    *  [*in the absence of any other information, the mean is typically the best estimate of the score for any single case in the distribution*]{.fragment fragment-index=3 style="color:#e93cac"}

::: {style="font-size:1.9em"}
$$
\Sigma(X_i -\bar{X})^2 = minimum
$$
:::
:::

## Important properties of the mean

1. Appropriate only for interval-ratio variables
    * must be able to assume consistent units/values for mathematical operations
2. Mathematical balancing point of the distribution
    * magnitude of scores below the mean balance the magnitude of scores above the mean
    * Example: Annual salary of a sample of teachers ($1000’s)
3. Sensitive to extremes

#### Self-reported male heights (inches) 

```{r}
#| echo: false
#| fig-width: 9
#| fig-height: 6
#| fig-align: center

library(dslabs)
library(ggthemes)
library(ggrepel)

set.seed(725)
heights_subset <- heights |> filter(sex == "Male") |> slice_sample(n = 10, replace = FALSE)

heights_subset |> 
ggplot(aes(y = height, x = sex)) +
geom_point(position = position_jitter(seed = 725), size = 2) +
geom_hline(data = (heights_subset |> filter(sex == "Male") |> summarise(mean_height = mean(height), .by = sex)), aes(yintercept = mean_height), color = "#e93cac") +
geom_label_repel(data = (heights_subset |> filter(sex == "Male") |> summarise(mean_height = round(mean(height), 2), .by = sex)), aes(x = sex, y = mean_height, label = mean_height), color = "#e93cac") +
ylim(65, 91) +
labs(x = "Sex", y = "Height (inches)") +
theme_tufte(base_size = 18) + 
theme(legend.position = "none")
```

--- 

#### [Adding cases at the mean has no effect on the mean]{style="color:#e93cac"}

```{r}
#| echo: false
#| fig-width: 9
#| fig-height: 6
#| fig-align: center

set.seed(725)
mean_point <- tibble(sex = rep("Male", 1), height = mean(heights_subset$height))
heights1 <- bind_rows(mean_point, heights_subset)
heights_subset |> 
ggplot(aes(y = height, x = sex)) +
geom_point(position = position_jitter(seed = 725), size = 2) +
geom_point(data = mean_point, aes(y = height, x = sex), color = "#2ad2c9", size = 3, alpha = 0.75) +
geom_hline(data = (heights1 |> filter(sex == "Male") |> summarise(mean_height = mean(height), .by = sex)), aes(yintercept = mean_height), color = "#e93cac") +
ylim(65, 91) +
labs(x = "Sex", y = "Height (inches)") +
geom_label_repel(data = (heights1 |> filter(sex == "Male") |> summarise(mean_height = round(mean(height), 2), .by = sex)), aes(x = sex, y = mean_height, label = mean_height), color = "#e93cac") +
theme_tufte(base_size = 18) + 
theme(legend.position = "none")
```

## Important properties of the mean

1. Appropriate only for interval-ratio variables
    * must be able to assume consistent units/values for mathematical operations
2. Mathematical balancing point of the distribution
    * magnitude of scores below the mean balance the magnitude of scores above the mean
    * Example: Annual salary of a sample of teachers ($1000’s)
3. Sensitive to extremes
    * [questionable measure of what is [**typical**]{.underline} when the distribution contains extreme values (skewed distributions)]{style="color:#e93cac"}
    * [but the mean retains usefulness in many statistical techniques, even when the distribution is skewed]{style="color:#e93cac"}

## Measure of central tendency: Median

::: {.fragment fragment-index=1}
::: r-fit-text
> [**Median**]{style="color:#e93cac"}<br> • The score for the case in the exact middle of the distribution<br>• The point in the distribution at which half of cases fall above<br>that score and half of the cases fall below that score<br>• 50th percentile of the distribution
:::
:::

<br>

::: {.fragment fragment-index=2}
#### [Calculation]{.underline}

1. [**Order**]{.underline style="color:#e93cac"} cases by score (low-to-high or high-to-low)
2. Find the [**median case**]{.underline style="color:#e93cac"} (i.e., “median rank”)
    * [**MEDIAN CASE = $\frac{N + 1}{2}$**]{style="color:#e93cac"}
3. Identify the [score]{.underline style="color:#e93cac"} associated with the median case.

:::

## Example calculation [*(with an odd number of cases)*]{style="font-size:0.75em"}

<br>

::: {.fragment fragment-index=1}
#### Hours of TV watch for a group of inmates 

[4, 2, 7, 6, 0, 6, 1, 3, 5]{style="font-size:1.5em"}
:::

::: {.fragment fragment-index=2}
#### Order the scores

[0, 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, 6, 7]{style="font-size:1.5em"}
:::

::: {.fragment fragment-index=3}
#### Median case

[$\frac{N + 1}{2} = \frac{9 + 1}{2} =$]{style="font-size:1.5em"} [5th case]{style="color:#e93cac; font-size:1.5em"}
:::

::: {.fragment fragment-index=3 data-id="box1" style="background: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0); border: 3px solid #e93cac; width: 35px; height: 35px; margin: 10px; position: absolute; top: 270px; left: 130px"}

:::

::: {.fragment fragment-index=4 data-id="box4" style="background: #ffc700; border: 4px solid #a68100; border-radius: 15px; width: 360px; height: 125px; padding: 0px 10px 20px 10px; position: absolute; top: 225px; left: 350px"}
Note that there are **four** cases with scores higher than the median and **four** with scores lower than the median
:::

::: {.fragment fragment-index=5 data-id="box3" style="background: #aadb1e; border: 4px solid #6e8e13; border-radius: 15px; width: 275px; height: 125px; padding: 0px 10px 20px 10px; position: absolute; bottom: 90px; left: 150px"}
The median for this distribution is the [score]{.underline} for the [case]{.underline} in the fifth ordered position
:::

## Example calculation [*(with an even number of cases)*]{style="font-size:0.75em"}

<br>

::: {.fragment fragment-index=1}
#### Hours of TV watch for a group of inmates 

[4, 2, 7, 6, 0, 6, 1, 3, 5, 0]{style="font-size:1.5em"}
:::

::: {.fragment fragment-index=2}
#### Order the scores

[0, 0, 1, 2, 3,]{style="font-size:1.5em"}[|]{.fragment fragment-index=3 style="color:#e93cac; font-size:1.5em"}[4, 5, 6, 6, 7]{style="font-size:1.5em"}
:::

::: {.fragment fragment-index=3}
#### Median case

[$\frac{N + 1}{2} = \frac{10 + 1}{2} =$]{style="font-size:1.5em"} [5.5th case]{style="color:#e93cac; font-size:1.5em"}
:::

::: {.fragment fragment-index=3 data-id="box1" style="background: rgba(255, 255, 255, 0); border: 3px solid #e93cac; width: 77px; height: 35px; margin: 10px; position: absolute; top: 269px; left: 134px"}

:::

::: {.fragment fragment-index=4 data-id="box4" style="background: #ffc700; border: 4px solid #a68100; border-radius: 15px; width: 360px; height: 125px; padding: 0px 10px 20px 10px; position: absolute; top: 225px; left: 400px"}
Note that there are **five** cases with scores higher than the median and **five** with scores lower than the median
:::

::: {.fragment fragment-index=5 data-id="box3" style="background: #aadb1e; border: 4px solid #6e8e13; border-radius: 15px; width: 475px; height: 200px; padding: 0px 10px 20px 10px; position: absolute; bottom: 0px; left: 150px"}
Median = score for the point halfway<br>between the 5th and 6th case. <br>
Score for 5th case = 3 <br>
Score for 6th case = 4 <br>
halfway between = [$\frac{3 + 4}{2} = 3.5$]{style="font-size:1.5em"}

::: 

---

### Calculating the median from a frequency distribution

::: {.smaller}
| Number of cups<br>(X)  | Frequency<br>(f)  | Percent<br>(%) | <br>Cf | <br>C%  |
|:--------:|:------:|:---:|---|---|
| 0 | 3 | 4.48 | 3 | 4.48 |

## Important properties of the median

1. Appropriate for interval-ratio or ordinal variables must be able to order scores
2. In comparison to the mean, the median is less affected by extreme scores 
    * but not completely unaffected
    * [**number of scores**]{style="color:#e93cac"}, not their magnitude, at different parts of the distribution [**is what matters**]{style="color:#e93cac"}…

#### Self-reported male heights (inches) 

```{r}
#| echo: false
#| fig-width: 9
#| fig-height: 6
#| fig-align: center

set.seed(725)
heights_subset <- heights |> filter(sex == "Male") |> slice_sample(n = 10, replace = FALSE)

heights_subset |> 
ggplot(aes(y = height, x = sex)) +
geom_point(size = 2) +
geom_hline(data = (heights_subset |> filter(sex == "Male") |> summarise(median_height = median(height), .by = sex)), aes(yintercept = median_height), color = "#e93cac", linetype = 2) +
geom_label_repel(data = (heights_subset |> filter(sex == "Male") |> summarise(median_height = round(median(height), 2), .by = sex)), aes(x = sex, y = median_height, label = median_height), color = "#e93cac") +
ylim(65, 91) +
labs(x = "Sex", y = "Height (inches)") +
theme_tufte(base_size = 18) + 
theme(legend.position = "none")
```

## Important properties of the mode

::: {.incremental}
1. Appropriate for any level of measurement
2. A distribution may have multiple modes
    * bimodal, trimodal, etc.
    * mode less useful in these situations (no longer a single number to convey what is typical)
:::

## Choosing a measure of central tendency

#### 3 criteria: 

::: {.incremental}
1. [Level of measurement]{style="background:#6e8e13"}
    * Limits options for central tendency
        * Interval variable: mode, median, or mean
        * Ordinal variable: mode or median
        * Nominal variable: mode
2. [Amount of information incorporated into the measure]{style="background:#1b8883"}
    * Mean uses most information, median the second most
3. [Shape of the distribution]{style="background:#a68100"}
    * Mean can give misleading picture of what is *common* or *typical* in a skewed distribution
    * But the mean is so commonly understood that, [with a skewed distribution]{.underline}, we often use **BOTH** the [median]{style="color:#e93cac"} and [mean]{style="color:#e93cac"}
:::

## Calculating the variance & standard deviation

1. Calculate the mean of the distribution
2. Subtract the mean from each score to get the deviation
3. Square each deviation
4. Sum the squared deviations
5. Divide the sum by n-1 to get the variance
6. Take the square root of the variance to get the standard deviation
